question_text:
Determine whether each of the following relations are reflexive, symmetric and transitive:
(i) Relation R in the set A = {1, 2, 3, ..., 13, 14} defined as R = {(x, y): x - y = 0}.
(ii) Relation R in the set ℕ of natural numbers defined as R = {(x, y): y = x + 5 and x < 4}.
(iii) Relation R in the set A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} given by R = {(x, y): y is divisible by x}.
(iv) Relation R in the set ℤ of all integers defined as R = {(x, y): x - y is an integer}.
(v) For the set A of human beings in a town at a particular time, consider:
 (a) R = {(x, y): x and y work at the same place}.
 (b) R = {(x, y): x and y live in the same locality}.
 (c) R = {(x, y): x is exactly 7 cm taller than y}.
 (d) R = {(x, y): x is wife of y}.
 (e) R = {(x, y): x is father of y}.
correct_answer:
(i) Since x - y = 0 if and only if x = y, the relation is the equality relation. It is reflexive (every element equals itself), symmetric (if x = y then y = x) and transitive (if x = y and y = z then x = z). 
(ii) For R = {(x, y): y = x + 5 with x < 4}, no element x satisfies x = x + 5 so the relation is not reflexive. Moreover, symmetry fails because if y = x + 5 it does not imply x = y + 5, and transitivity fails in general since chaining such relations does not yield the required form. 
(iii) In R = {(x, y): y is divisible by x} on A = {1,2,3,4,5,6}, every number divides itself so it is reflexive. However, symmetry does not hold (e.g. 2 divides 4 but 4 does not divide 2) while transitivity holds (if x divides y and y divides z then x divides z). 
(iv) For R = {(x, y): x - y is an integer} on ℤ, note that the difference of any two integers is an integer. Hence R = ℤ × ℤ, which is reflexive, symmetric and transitive. 
(v) (a) 'Works at the same place' is reflexive (everyone works at their own place), symmetric (if x works with y then y works with x) and transitive (if x and y work together and y and z work together, then x and z work together), so it is an equivalence relation. 
(b) 'Lives in the same locality' is similarly an equivalence relation. 
(c) 'x is exactly 7 cm taller than y' is not reflexive (no one is 7 cm taller than themselves), not symmetric (if x is 7 cm taller than y then y is not 7 cm taller than x) and not transitive (if x is 7 cm taller than y and y is 7 cm taller than z, then x is 14 cm taller than z, not 7 cm), so none of the properties hold. 
(d) 'x is wife of y' is not reflexive (no one is her own wife), not symmetric (wifehood does not reverse) and not transitive. 
(e) 'x is father of y' is similarly not reflexive, not symmetric and not transitive.
explanation: For (i), recognize that x - y = 0 precisely when x = y; hence every element is related only to itself. For (ii), check for reflexivity by testing if x equals x+5 (which is impossible) and similarly observe that the condition does not reverse for symmetry. For (iii), use the fact that divisibility is reflexive and transitive by definition but fails symmetry in many cases. For (iv), note that every difference of two integers is an integer, so the relation is universal. For (v), analyze each sub-part using the definitions of reflexivity, symmetry and transitivity in the context of real-world properties.

question_text: Show that the relation R in the set ℝ of real numbers, defined as R = {(a, b): a ≤ b²}, is neither reflexive nor symmetric nor transitive.
correct_answer: The relation is not reflexive because for some a in ℝ the inequality a ≤ a² fails (e.g., a = -1 or 0 < a < 1). It is not symmetric since a ≤ b² does not imply b ≤ a². It is not transitive because even if a ≤ b² and b ≤ c², it does not follow in general that a ≤ c².
explanation: To show non-reflexivity, choose a counterexample such as a = -1, where -1 ≤ (-1)² (i.e. -1 ≤ 1) holds but note that for values like 0.5, 0.5 ≤ (0.5)² (0.5 ≤ 0.25) does not hold. For symmetry, assume a ≤ b² but the reverse b ≤ a² may fail (choose appropriate a, b). For transitivity, select numbers that satisfy the first two relations but violate the third. A concrete counterexample can be constructed by testing specific values.

question_text: Check whether the relation R defined in the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} as R = {(a, b): b = a + 1} is reflexive, symmetric or transitive.
correct_answer: The relation is not reflexive since no element satisfies a = a + 1. It is not symmetric because if b = a + 1, then it is not generally true that a = b + 1. It is not transitive because although (a, a+1) and (a+1, a+2) are in R, (a, a+2) is not in R.
explanation: Reflexivity requires each element a to satisfy a = a + 1, which is impossible. For symmetry, notice that the condition is one directional. For transitivity, observe that the rule only connects consecutive numbers, so a jump over two steps does not satisfy the relation.

question_text: Show that the relation R in ℝ defined as R = {(a, b): a ≤ b} is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric.
correct_answer: The relation is reflexive because for every a ∈ ℝ, a ≤ a holds. It is transitive since if a ≤ b and b ≤ c then a ≤ c. It is not symmetric because a ≤ b does not imply b ≤ a unless a = b.
explanation: By definition, every real number satisfies a ≤ a, ensuring reflexivity. The order relation on ℝ is known to be transitive. However, symmetry fails because, for instance, 3 ≤ 5 is true but 5 ≤ 3 is false.

question_text: Check whether the relation R in ℝ defined by R = {(a, b): a ≤ b³} is reflexive, symmetric or transitive.
correct_answer: The relation R is not reflexive because for many a the condition a ≤ a³ does not hold (consider a between 0 and 1 or negative numbers). It is not symmetric since a ≤ b³ does not imply b ≤ a³. It is not transitive because even if a ≤ b³ and b ≤ c³ hold, it does not guarantee that a ≤ c³.
explanation: Test reflexivity by taking specific examples (e.g., a = 0.5 gives 0.5 ≤ 0.125 which is false). For symmetry, a counterexample can be found where the inequality works one way but not the other. For transitivity, one can provide numerical examples showing that the composite relation does not hold.

question_text: Show that the relation R in the set {1, 2, 3} given by R = {(1, 2), (2, 1)} is symmetric but neither reflexive nor transitive.
correct_answer: The relation is symmetric because (1, 2) and (2, 1) are both present. It is not reflexive because there are no pairs of the form (1, 1), (2, 2), or (3, 3). It is not transitive because, for example, (1, 2) and (2, 1) would require (1, 1) to be present for transitivity, which it is not.
explanation: By definition, a relation is symmetric if whenever (a, b) is in R, (b, a) is also in R. Here that holds. However, reflexivity fails because not every element is related to itself. In addition, the lack of (1, 1) makes the relation non-transitive.

question_text: Show that the relation R in the set A of all the books in a college library, given by R = {(x, y): x and y have the same number of pages}, is an equivalence relation.
correct_answer: The relation is an equivalence relation because it is reflexive (every book has the same number of pages as itself), symmetric (if book x has the same number of pages as book y, then y has the same number as x) and transitive (if x and y have the same number of pages, and y and z do as well, then x and z have the same number of pages).
explanation: Verify reflexivity by observing that any book x satisfies the condition with itself. For symmetry, if x has the same page count as y, then by equality the reverse holds. Transitivity follows from the transitivity of equality.

question_text: Show that the relation R in the set A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5} defined by R = {(a, b): |a – b| is even} is an equivalence relation. Also, show that all the elements of {1, 3, 5} are related to each other and all the elements of {2, 4} are related to each other, but no element of {1, 3, 5} is related to any element of {2, 4}.
correct_answer: The relation is an equivalence relation since it is reflexive (|a – a| = 0, which is even), symmetric (|a – b| = |b – a|) and transitive (if |a – b| and |b – c| are even, then |a – c| is even). The equivalence classes partition the set as follows: {1, 3, 5} (all odd numbers) and {2, 4} (all even numbers), with no cross-relations between them.
explanation:
Check each property in turn: 
Reflexivity: For any a ∈ A, |a – a| = 0 is even. 
Symmetry: The absolute difference is symmetric. 
Transitivity: The sum of two even numbers is even. 
Since odd numbers have even differences among themselves and the same for even numbers, the partition is as described.

question_text:
Show that each of the following relations in the set A = {x ∈ ℤ : 0 ≤ x ≤ 12} is an equivalence relation and find the set of all elements related to 1 in each case:
(i) R = {(a, b): |a – b| is a multiple of 4}.
(ii) R = {(a, b): a = b}.
correct_answer:
For (i): The relation defined by |a – b| being a multiple of 4 is an equivalence relation because it is reflexive (|a – a| = 0, a multiple of 4), symmetric and transitive (properties of congruence modulo 4). The equivalence class of 1 is [1] = {1, 5, 9}.
For (ii): The relation a = b is the equality relation, which is trivially an equivalence relation with the equivalence class of 1 being {1}.
explanation: For (i), observe that the condition is equivalent to a ≡ b (mod 4) on the finite set. This relation partitions A into subsets where each element has the same remainder upon division by 4. For (ii), the equality relation only relates an element with itself.

question_text:
Give an example of a relation that is:
(i) Symmetric but neither reflexive nor transitive.
(ii) Transitive but neither reflexive nor symmetric.
(iii) Reflexive and symmetric but not transitive.
(iv) Reflexive and transitive but not symmetric.
(v) Symmetric and transitive but not reflexive.
correct_answer:
Examples (one possible set of answers):
(i) On the set {1, 2}, let R = {(1,2), (2,1)}. It is symmetric but lacks (1,1) and (2,2), so not reflexive; and it fails transitivity because (1,2) and (2,1) would require (1,1).
(ii) On the set {1, 2, 3}, let R = {(1,2), (2,3), (1,3)}. This relation is transitive but not reflexive (no (1,1), etc.) and not symmetric.
(iii) On the set {1, 2, 3}, let R = {(1,1), (2,2), (3,3), (1,2), (2,1), (2,3), (3,2)}. It is reflexive and symmetric but fails transitivity since (1,2) and (2,3) would require (1,3), which is missing.
(iv) The relation ≤ on ℝ is reflexive and transitive (the usual order) but not symmetric.
(v) On the set {1,2}, again let R = {(1,2), (2,1)}. This relation is symmetric and transitive (trivially, since there is no chain forcing reflexivity) but not reflexive because (1,1) and (2,2) are missing.
explanation: For each part, one must craft a relation that meets the criteria. In (i), symmetry holds by having matching reverse pairs but reflexivity fails as no element is related to itself. In (ii), transitivity is forced by the chain (1,2) and (2,3) yielding (1,3) while not including self-relations or reversals to satisfy reflexivity or symmetry. The other parts are handled similarly by checking each property against the definition.
topic: Relations - Constructing examples with specific properties

question_text: Show that the relation R in the set A of points in a plane, defined by R = {(P, Q): the distance of point P from the origin is the same as the distance of point Q from the origin}, is an equivalence relation. Further, show that for any point P ≠ (0, 0), the set of all points related to P is the circle with center at the origin passing through P.
correct_answer:
The relation is an equivalence relation because: 
– Reflexivity: every point is at the same distance from the origin as itself.
– Symmetry: if the distance from P to the origin equals that of Q, then the distance from Q equals that of P.
– Transitivity: if P and Q have the same distance from the origin and Q and R do as well, then P and R have the same distance. 
Furthermore, for any P ≠ (0, 0) with distance r from the origin, the set of all Q with distance r forms the circle centered at the origin with radius r.
explanation:
Check each property: 
Reflexivity is immediate; symmetry follows since equality of distances is symmetric; transitivity is due to the fact that equality is transitive. The equivalence class (set of points with equal distance) relative to any point P ≠ (0, 0) is exactly the circle described.

question_text: Show that the relation R defined in the set A of all triangles as R = {(T₁, T₂): T₁ is similar to T₂} is an equivalence relation. Consider the right-angled triangles T₁ with sides 3, 4, 5; T₂ with sides 5, 12, 13; and T₃ with sides 6, 8, 10. Which triangles among T₁, T₂ and T₃ are related?
correct_answer: The relation is an equivalence relation since similarity of triangles is reflexive (each triangle is similar to itself), symmetric (if T₁ is similar to T₂ then T₂ is similar to T₁) and transitive (if T₁ ~ T₂ and T₂ ~ T₃, then T₁ ~ T₃). Among the triangles, T₁ (3,4,5) and T₃ (6,8,10) are similar (T₃ is a scaled version of T₁), whereas T₂ (5,12,13) is not similar to T₁ or T₃.
explanation: Verify the three properties using the definition of similarity. For the examples, compute the ratios of corresponding sides to confirm that the triangle with sides 6,8,10 is similar to the triangle with sides 3,4,5, while the triangle with sides 5,12,13 does not have the same proportionality.

question_text: Show that the relation R defined in the set A of all polygons as R = {(P₁, P₂): P₁ and P₂ have the same number of sides} is an equivalence relation. What is the set of all elements in A related to the right-angled triangle T with sides 3, 4, 5?
correct_answer: The relation is an equivalence relation because having the same number of sides is reflexive (any polygon has the same number of sides as itself), symmetric (if P₁ has the same number of sides as P₂, then P₂ has the same as P₁) and transitive (if P₁ and P₂ have the same number of sides and P₂ and P₃ do as well, then P₁ and P₃ have the same number of sides). The equivalence class of the right-angled triangle T consists of all polygons with 3 sides, i.e., all triangles.
explanation: Since the relation groups polygons based solely on the number of sides, the equivalence class of any triangle is the set of all triangles. This partitioning into triangles, quadrilaterals, etc., satisfies the three properties required for an equivalence relation.

question_text: Let L be the set of all lines in the XY-plane and let R be the relation defined as R = {(L₁, L₂): L₁ is parallel to L₂}. Show that R is an equivalence relation. Find the set of all lines related to the line y = 2x + 4.
correct_answer:
The relation is an equivalence relation because: 
– Reflexivity: every line is parallel to itself.
– Symmetry: if L₁ is parallel to L₂ then L₂ is parallel to L₁.
– Transitivity: if L₁ is parallel to L₂ and L₂ is parallel to L₃ then L₁ is parallel to L₃. 
The equivalence class of the line y = 2x + 4 is the set of all lines with slope 2.
explanation: Parallelism among lines satisfies all three conditions (reflexive, symmetric, transitive). Thus, all lines sharing the same slope as y = 2x + 4 (i.e. slope 2) form its equivalence class.

question_text:
Let R be the relation in the set {1, 2, 3, 4} given by R = {(1, 2), (2, 2), (1, 1), (4, 4), (1, 3), (3, 3), (3, 2)}. Choose the correct answer:
(A) R is reflexive and symmetric but not transitive.
(B) R is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric.
(C) R is symmetric and transitive but not reflexive.
(D) R is an equivalence relation.
options: A: R is reflexive and symmetric but not transitive.
B: R is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric.
C: R is symmetric and transitive but not reflexive.
D: R is an equivalence relation.
correct_answer: B: R is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric.
explanation: First, check reflexivity: every element in {1, 2, 3, 4} is related to itself ((1,1), (2,2), (3,3), and (4,4) are present). Next, symmetry fails because although (1,2) is in R, the reverse (2,1) is missing. For transitivity, for instance, (1,3) and (3,2) are in R and (1,2) is also present. Therefore, the relation is reflexive and transitive but not symmetric.

question_text:
Let R be the relation in the set ℕ defined by R = {(a, b): a = b², with b > 6}. Choose the correct answer:
(A) (2, 4) ∈ R
(B) (3, 8) ∈ R
(C) (6, 8) ∈ R
(D) (8, 7) ∈ R
correct_answer: None of the provided pairs satisfy the condition a = b² with b > 6.
explanation:
Examine each option:
For (2,4): 4² = 16 ≠ 2.
For (3,8): 8² = 64 ≠ 3.
For (6,8): 8² = 64 ≠ 6.
For (8,7): 7² = 49 ≠ 8.
Since none of the ordered pairs satisfy a = b² with b > 6, none of the options are correct.

question_text: Which of the following best describes the composition of two functions f and g?
options: g ∘ f is defined as x ↦ f(g(x))
g ∘ f is defined as x ↦ g(f(x))
g ∘ f is defined as x ↦ f(x) + g(x)
g ∘ f is defined as x ↦ g(x) - f(x)
correct_answer: g ∘ f is defined as x ↦ g(f(x))
explanation: By definition, given f: A → B and g: B → C, the composition g ∘ f is the function from A to C such that (g ∘ f)(x) = g(f(x)) for every x in A.

question_text: Given functions f: {2, 3, 4, 5} → {3, 4, 5, 9} defined by f(2)=3, f(3)=4, f(4)=5, f(5)=5 and g: {3, 4, 5, 9} → {7, 11, 15} defined by g(3)=7, g(4)=7, g(5)=11 and g(9)=11, what is the value of (g ∘ f)(3)?
explanation: First, compute f(3)=4. Then use the function g: g(4)=7. Hence, (g ∘ f)(3)=7.

question_text: Which statement is true regarding an invertible function f: X → Y?
options: f must be one-to-one, but need not be onto
f must be onto, but need not be one-to-one
f must be both one-to-one and onto
f can be invertible regardless of being one-to-one or onto
correct_answer: f must be both one-to-one and onto
explanation: A function is invertible if and only if it is a bijection; that is, it must be both one-to-one and onto.

question_text: Consider the functions f(x)=cos x and g(x)=3x² defined on ℝ. Which of the following is a correct observation?
options: g ∘ f = f ∘ g for all x ∈ ℝ
g ∘ f = 3cos² x and f ∘ g = cos 3x², which are equal for all x ∈ ℝ
g ∘ f = 3cos² x and f ∘ g = cos 3x², and they are not equal (e.g., at x=0)
Both compositions simplify to the same constant function
correct_answer: g ∘ f = 3cos² x and f ∘ g = cos 3x², and they are not equal (e.g., at x=0)
explanation: Calculating the compositions, g ∘ f(x)=3(cos x)² and f ∘ g(x)=cos(3x²). At x=0, g ∘ f(0)=3(1)=3 and f ∘ g(0)=cos 0=1, hence they differ.

question_text: Define the composition of two functions and provide its formal mathematical notation.
correct_answer: If f: A → B and g: B → C are functions, then the composition g ∘ f is a function from A to C defined by (g ∘ f)(x) = g(f(x)) for every x in A.
explanation: The composition of functions is a process where the output of one function becomes the input of another. The formal notation is (g ∘ f)(x)=g(f(x)).

question_text: What does it mean for a function f: X → Y to be invertible? Provide the necessary conditions.
correct_answer: A function f is invertible if there exists a function g: Y → X such that g ∘ f = Iₓ and f ∘ g = Iᵧ. This means f must be both one-to-one and onto.
explanation: Invertibility means there is a unique inverse function g satisfying g(f(x))=x for all x in X and f(g(y))=y for all y in Y. This requires f to be bijective (one-to-one and onto).

question_text: Provide an example (other than those given in the textbook) of two functions f and g whose composition can be explicitly computed. Briefly describe your example and compute (g ∘ f)(x).
correct_answer: For example, let f: ℝ → ℝ be defined by f(x) = x + 2 and let g: ℝ → ℝ be defined by g(x) = 2x. Then, (g ∘ f)(x) = g(x + 2) = 2(x + 2) = 2x + 4.
explanation: In this example, f shifts any input by 2 and g doubles the input. Their composition involves applying f first and then g, resulting in (g ∘ f)(x)=2(x+2)=2x+4.

question_text: For the functions f(x)=cos x and g(x)=3x², explain why (g ∘ f) and (f ∘ g) yield different results. Illustrate with a specific value of x.
correct_answer: For x=0, (g ∘ f)(0)=3(cos 0)²=3×1=3, whereas (f ∘ g)(0)=cos(3×0²)=cos 0=1. The difference arises because the order of operations matters when composing functions.
explanation: When composing functions, the inner function's output becomes the input for the outer function. Since f and g are nonlinear, the operations do not commute, thus (g ∘ f)(x) and (f ∘ g)(x) are generally different.

question_text: Prove that if a function f : X → Y is invertible, then f must be one-to-one and onto.
correct_answer: Proof: Assume that f has an inverse g: Y → X such that g ∘ f = Iₓ and f ∘ g = Iᵧ. To show f is one-to-one, suppose f(x₁)= f(x₂) for some x₁, x₂ in X. Then applying g to both sides gives g(f(x₁)) = g(f(x₂)), which means x₁ = x₂. To show onto, for every y in Y, consider x = g(y). Then f(x)= f(g(y))= y. Hence, every y in Y has a pre-image in X. Thus, f is bijective.
explanation: The existence of an inverse function means every output of f is uniquely reached (one-to-one) and every element in Y is hit (onto). Applying the inverse function to both sides of the equation f(x₁)= f(x₂) shows uniqueness, and writing y = f(g(y)) confirms surjectivity.

question_text: Let f : ℕ → Y be defined by f(x) = 4x + 3, where Y = { y ∈ ℕ : y = 4x + 3 for some x ∈ ℕ }. Prove that f is invertible and find its inverse function.
correct_answer: To prove invertibility, observe that for every y ∈ Y, there exists a unique x ∈ ℕ such that y = 4x+3. Solving for x gives x = (y-3)/4. Define g: Y → ℕ by g(y) = (y-3)/4. Verify that (g ∘ f)(x) = g(4x+3) = (4x+3-3)/4 = x, and (f ∘ g)(y) = f((y-3)/4) = 4((y-3)/4) + 3 = y. Therefore, f is invertible and its inverse is g(y) = (y-3)/4.
explanation: The invertibility follows by showing that every output y from f corresponds uniquely to an input x. The steps involve solving the equation y = 4x+3 and then verifying that the composed functions yield the identity functions on their respective domains.

explanation: Step 1: Compute cos (π/3)=0.5, then (g ∘ f)(π/3)=3 (0.5)²=0.75. Step 2: For (f ∘ g)(π/3), first compute g(π/3)=3(π/3)²=π²/3, so (f ∘ g)(π/3)=cos (π²/3).

question_text: Let f: {1, 2, 3} → {2, 4, 6} be defined by f(1)=2, f(2)=4, f(3)=6, and g: {2, 4, 6} → {3, 5, 7} be defined by g(2)=3, g(4)=5, g(6)=7. Find the composite function (g ∘ f) for each element in the domain.
explanation: Compute each value: For x=1, f(1)=2 then g(2)=3. For x=2, f(2)=4 then g(4)=5. For x=3, f(3)=6 then g(6)=7.

question_text: Given f(x)=2x+1 and g(x)=x-1, compute the composite function (f ∘ g)(x) and determine if (f ∘ g) is invertible by finding its inverse.
correct_answer: (f ∘ g)(x)= f(g(x)) = 2(x-1)+1 = 2x-2+1 = 2x-1. Its inverse, h, satisfies h(y)= (y+1)/2, so the inverse is (f ∘ g)⁻¹ (y)= (y+1)/2.
explanation: Step 1: Find (f ∘ g)(x): Substitute g(x)=x-1 into f to get 2(x-1)+1=2x-2+1=2x-1. Step 2: To find the inverse, set y=2x-1 and solve for x giving x=(y+1)/2.

question_text: Let f(x)=x³ and g(x)=√x, with the domain of g being x ≥ 0. Compute (g ∘ f)(2) and state the domain and range of the composite function.
correct_answer: (g ∘ f)(2)=√(2³)=√8=2√2. The domain of (g ∘ f) is all x ∈ ℝ such that f(x) ≥0. Since f(x)=x³ is nonnegative when x ≥ 0, the domain is [0,∞) and the range is [0,∞).
explanation: Step 1: Calculate f(2)=2³=8 and then g(8)=√8=2√2. Step 2: Since g is defined for nonnegative inputs and f(x)=x³ is nonnegative for x≥0, the composite (g ∘ f) is defined for x ≥0. Moreover, √(x³) produces nonnegative outputs.

question_text: Show that the function f : ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = 1 + x|x| is one–one and onto.
correct_answer: f is injective because if 1 + x₁|x₁| = 1 + x₂|x₂| then x₁|x₁| = x₂|x₂| which implies x₁ = x₂ after considering the cases x ≥ 0 and x < 0. It is surjective because for any y ∈ ℝ one can find an x ∈ ℝ (x = √(y – 1) for y ≥ 1 and x = –√(1 – y) for y < 1) such that f(x) = y.
explanation:
Step 1: To prove injectivity, assume f(x₁) = f(x₂). That is, 1 + x₁|x₁| = 1 + x₂|x₂|. Cancel 1 to get x₁|x₁| = x₂|x₂|. Now, consider two cases:
(a) For nonnegative x, |x| = x so the equation becomes x₁² = x₂² and since both x₁ and x₂ are nonnegative, we deduce x₁ = x₂.
(b) For negative x, |x| = –x so the equation becomes –x₁² = –x₂², implying x₁² = x₂² and since both are negative, x₁ = x₂. Also, if one of x₁, x₂ is negative and the other nonnegative, the left–sides will have different signs, a contradiction.
Step 2: To prove surjectivity, take any y ∈ ℝ. Notice that for x ≥ 0, f(x) = 1 + x², so if y ≥ 1, let x = √(y – 1) which yields f(x) = y. For x < 0, f(x) = 1 – x²; thus, if y < 1, set x = –√(1 – y) to obtain f(x) = y. Therefore every y ∈ ℝ has a pre–image, proving surjectivity.

question_text: Show that the function f : ℝ → ℝ given by f(x) = x³ is injective.
correct_answer: f is injective because if x₁³ = x₂³ then taking cube roots (or using the fact that the cubic function is strictly increasing) one obtains x₁ = x₂.
explanation: Assume f(x₁) = f(x₂), i.e. x₁³ = x₂³. The cubic function is strictly increasing on ℝ, so the equality implies x₁ = x₂. Hence the function is one–one.

question_text: Given a non empty set X, consider P(X), the set of all subsets of X. Define a relation R in P(X) as follows: for subsets A, B in P(X), A R B if and only if A ⊂ B. Is R an equivalence relation on P(X)? Justify your answer.
correct_answer: R is not an equivalence relation because it fails to be reflexive (since no set is a strict subset of itself) and in general fails symmetry and transitivity as required.
explanation:
An equivalence relation must be reflexive, symmetric, and transitive.
• Reflexivity: For every A ∈ P(X), we should have A R A. However, since the relation is defined by strict subset (A ⊂ A is false), R is not reflexive.
• Without reflexivity, R cannot be an equivalence relation. Thus, R is not an equivalence relation on P(X).

question_text: Find the number of all onto functions from the set {1, 2, 3, …, n} to itself.
correct_answer: The number of onto functions from a set of n elements to itself is n! (since every onto function is a bijection).
explanation: For a function f from a finite set A to itself (with n elements) to be onto, every element of A must be mapped to; that is, f must be a bijection. The number of bijections from a set of n elements to itself is exactly n!.

question_text: Let A = {–1, 0, 1, 2} and B = {–4, –2, 0, 2}. Define the functions f, g : A → B by f(x) = x² – x and g(x) = 2|x – 1/2| – 1, for all x ∈ A. Are f and g equal? Justify your answer.
correct_answer: The functions f and g are equal because for every x ∈ A, f(x) and g(x) yield the same value. In particular, f(–1)=2, f(0)=0, f(1)=0, f(2)=2, and similarly g(–1)=2, g(0)=0, g(1)=0, g(2)=2.

question_text: Let A = {1, 2, 3}. Determine the number of relations on A that are reflexive and symmetric, contain the pairs (1,2) and (1,3), but are not transitive.
explanation: Since the relation must be reflexive, it must contain (1,1), (2,2), and (3,3). Given that (1,2) and (1,3) are in the relation, by symmetry, (2,1) and (3,1) must also be included. The only remaining potential pair is (2,3) along with its symmetric pair (3,2). Including these would force transitivity (since (2,1) and (1,3) would then require (2,3)) resulting in an equivalence relation. To ensure the relation is not transitive, these optional pairs must be omitted. Hence, there is exactly one relation satisfying these conditions.

question_text: Let A = {1, 2, 3}. Determine the number of equivalence relations on A that contain the pair (1,2).
explanation: An equivalence relation on a finite set corresponds to a partition of the set into disjoint subsets (equivalence classes). The condition that (1,2) is in the relation forces 1 and 2 to belong to the same equivalence class. For A = {1, 2, 3}, there are two possibilities: either 3 is in the same equivalence class as 1 and 2 or 3 forms its own separate class. Hence, there are 2 equivalence relations satisfying the condition.

question_text: Which of the following statements is the correct definition of a one‐one (injective) function?
options: A function f is one‐one if for every x₁, x₂ in the domain, f(x₁) = f(x₂) implies x₁ = x₂.
A function f is one‐one if every element in the codomain is the image of some element in the domain.
A function f is one‐one if it maps every element of the domain to the same element in the codomain.
A function f is one‐one if its domain and codomain have the same number of elements.
correct_answer: A function f is one‐one if for every x₁, x₂ in the domain, f(x₁) = f(x₂) implies x₁ = x₂.
explanation: This is the precise definition of an injective function. It guarantees that different inputs produce different outputs. The other options either refer to surjectivity or are incorrect descriptions.

question_text: Consider the function f: ℝ* → ℝ* defined by f(x) = 1/x, where ℝ* is the set of all non‐zero real numbers. Which of the following is true when the domain is ℝ*?
options: f is one‐one but not onto.
f is onto but not one‐one.
f is both one‐one and onto.
f is neither one‐one nor onto.
correct_answer: f is both one‐one and onto.
explanation: For every non-zero real number x, 1/x gives a unique non-zero value and every non-zero real number y has a preimage (namely 1/y). Hence, f is both injective and surjective when the domain is ℝ*.

question_text: Let f: ℕ → ℕ be defined by f(x) = 2x, where ℕ is the set of natural numbers. Which statement best describes this function?
options: f is one‐one and onto.
f is one‐one but not onto.
f is onto but not one‐one.
f is neither one‐one nor onto.
correct_answer: f is one‐one but not onto.
explanation: The function f(x) = 2x is injective because no two different naturals give the same even number. However, it is not surjective on ℕ since odd numbers in ℕ are not produced by any x in ℕ.

question_text: Suppose f is a function from a finite set X to itself. Which of the following statements is always true?
options: If f is one‐one then f is onto.
If f is onto then f is one‐one.
Both (A) and (B) are true.
Neither (A) nor (B) is true without further conditions.
correct_answer: Both (A) and (B) are true.
explanation: For functions on finite sets, an injective (one‐one) function is necessarily surjective (onto) and vice versa. This is a classic result from elementary set theory concerning finite sets.

question_text: Define an 'onto' (surjective) function and give one example with a brief explanation.
correct_answer: An onto (surjective) function f: X → Y is one in which every element y in the codomain Y is the image of at least one element x in the domain X. For example, the function f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = 2x is onto because for every y in ℝ, there exists x = y/2 such that f(x) = y.
explanation: The definition states that the range of f must equal the entire codomain. The example f(x) = 2x clearly meets this condition as each y has a corresponding preimage x = y/2.

question_text: Explain the difference between a one‐one function and a many‐one function. Provide an example of each.
correct_answer: A one‐one function (injective) maps distinct elements of the domain to distinct elements of the codomain. In contrast, a many‐one function maps at least two distinct elements of the domain to the same element in the codomain. For example, f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = 2x is one‐one, while f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = x² is many‐one since f(1) = f(-1) = 1.
explanation: Understanding the mapping properties is crucial. A one‐one function ensures no two different inputs produce the same output, whereas a many‐one function violates this condition, as shown in the provided examples.

question_text: What is a bijective function? Explain its significance in terms of invertibility, and provide a concise definition.
correct_answer: A bijective function is a function that is both one‐one (injective) and onto (surjective). This means every element in the domain maps to a unique element in the codomain, and every element in the codomain has a preimage. Bijective functions are significant because they allow for the construction of inverse functions.
explanation: Bijectivity is critical in many areas of mathematics because the existence of an inverse function f⁻¹ is guaranteed if and only if f is bijective. The clear definition indicates the one-to-one correspondence between sets.

question_text: Prove that an onto (surjective) function f from a finite set X to X must be one‐one (injective). Provide a detailed explanation using a counting argument.
correct_answer: Since X is finite, suppose it has n elements. If f: X → X is onto, then every element in X is the image of some element of X. If f were not one‐one, at least two distinct elements would map to the same element in X. This means the number of distinct images would be less than n, contradicting the fact that the function is onto. Therefore, f must be one‐one.
explanation: Step 1: Assume that f is onto and X has n elements. Step 2: If f is not one‐one, then fewer than n distinct values are produced. Step 3: This contradicts the onto property, which requires that all n elements of X appear as images. Thus, injectivity is forced in any function from a finite set to itself that is surjective.

question_text: Prove that the function f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = 2x is bijective. In your proof, demonstrate both injectivity and surjectivity with detailed steps.
correct_answer: To prove bijectivity, we show injectivity and surjectivity. Injectivity: Assume f(x₁) = f(x₂). Then 2x₁ = 2x₂, so dividing both sides by 2, we get x₁ = x₂. Hence, f is injective. Surjectivity: For any y in ℝ, let x = y/2. Then f(x) = 2(y/2) = y, proving that every y in ℝ has a preimage in ℝ. Therefore, f is surjective. Since f is both injective and surjective, it is bijective.
explanation: The proof is split into two parts: first, showing that no two distinct x values yield the same f(x) (injectivity), and second, demonstrating that every y in the codomain is reached by some x (surjectivity). This standard method confirms the function is bijective.

question_text: Let f: ℝ → ℝ be defined by f(x) = x². Compute f(3) and explain why this function is not injective.
correct_answer: f(3) = 9. The function is not injective because different inputs can yield the same output; for instance, f(3) = 9 and f(-3) = 9, so it fails the one‐one criterion.
explanation: Step 1: Substitute x = 3 into the function: f(3) = 3² = 9. Step 2: Note that f(-3) = (-3)² = 9 as well. Since f(3) = f(-3) but 3 ≠ -3, the function is not one‐one.

question_text: Examine whether the function f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = x² is injective or surjective. Justify your answers with detailed reasoning.
correct_answer: The function f(x) = x² is not injective because f(1) = 1 and f(-1) = 1, meaning different inputs produce the same output. It is also not surjective because negative numbers in ℝ cannot be expressed as x² for any real x.
explanation: Injectivity: f(1) = 1 and f(-1) = 1; since 1 ≠ -1, the function is not one‐one. Surjectivity: For any y < 0, there is no real x such that x² = y. Hence, not every element of ℝ is an output of the function.

question_text: Let f: ℤ → ℤ be defined by f(x) = x³. Verify whether this function is injective and surjective. Provide a step-by-step explanation.
correct_answer: The function f(x) = x³ is injective because if x₁³ = x₂³, then x₁ = x₂. It is surjective for ℤ because for every integer y, the cube root of y is an integer when y is a perfect cube; however, for general integers, note that every integer is a perfect cube of some integer only if the domain and codomain are restricted to ℤ. In ℤ, every integer y is indeed the cube of its cube root if we allow cube roots that are integers (since the cube function is strictly increasing and covers all of ℤ).
explanation: Injectivity: Assume x₁³ = x₂³. Since the cube function is strictly increasing over ℤ, it implies x₁ = x₂. Surjectivity: For any y in ℤ, set x = ∛y. Since the cube function is bijective from ℤ to ℤ (each integer cube is unique and every integer is achieved), f is surjective. Therefore, f is both injective and surjective over ℤ.

question_text: Let f: ℕ → ℕ be defined by f(1) = f(2) = 1 and f(x) = x - 1 for every x > 2. Show that f is onto but not one‐one. Illustrate your answer with numerical examples.
correct_answer: f is not one‐one because f(1) = 1 and f(2) = 1, i.e., two distinct inputs produce the same output. However, f is onto since for every natural number y, if y = 1 then f(1) = 1, and for y > 1, choose x = y + 1 so that f(x) = (y + 1) - 1 = y. Hence, f is surjective.
explanation: Step 1: Check that f(1) = 1 and f(2) = 1, proving non-injectivity. Step 2: For any y in ℕ, if y = 1, f(1)=1; if y > 1 take x = y + 1 then f(x) = y+1 - 1 = y. Therefore, every y in ℕ has a preimage, establishing surjectivity.

question_text: Which of the following best defines a relation R from a set A to a set B?
options: A rule that assigns exactly one element of B to every element of A
An arbitrary subset of A×B
A function that satisfies the vertical line test
A one-to-one correspondence between A and B
correct_answer: An arbitrary subset of A×B
explanation: Mathematically, a relation from a set A to a set B is defined as any subset of the Cartesian product A×B. Unlike functions, there is no requirement of uniqueness or existence for every element in A.

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding functions?
options: Every relation is a function.
A function is any subset of A×B.
A function is a relation with a unique output for every input in its domain.
A function can assign more than one output for an input if the domain is infinite.
correct_answer: A function is a relation with a unique output for every input in its domain.
explanation: A function is a special kind of relation. For every element in the domain, the function must assign one and only one output in the co-domain. This distinguishes functions from general relations.

question_text: Given sets A and B, if R ⊆ A×B, then which of these is a necessary statement about any relation R?
options: R must describe an explicit connection between elements of A and B.
R must be a function if A and B are non-empty.
R may or may not exhibit a recognizable link between the elements of A and B.
R is always one-to-one.
correct_answer: R may or may not exhibit a recognizable link between the elements of A and B.
explanation: Although examples in everyday language might suggest a meaningful connection, mathematically a relation is any subset of A×B regardless of whether there is a recognisable link between the elements.

question_text: Functions are special kinds of relations. Which property distinguishes a function from a general relation?
options: It is defined on the entire set B.
Every element in A relates to at least one element in B.
Every element in A is related to exactly one element in B.
The relation is symmetric.
correct_answer: Every element in A is related to exactly one element in B.
explanation: The defining property of a function is that each element of its domain (here, A) is assigned exactly one element in its co-domain, which differentiates it from a general relation where this uniqueness condition need not hold.

question_text: Define the terms 'domain', 'co-domain', and 'range' in the context of functions.
correct_answer: The domain of a function is the set of all inputs for which the function is defined. The co-domain is the set that contains all possible outputs, as prescribed by the definition of the function. The range (or image) is the actual set of outputs produced by the function.
explanation:
• Domain: All possible valid input values.
• Co-domain: The set which includes all potential outputs as defined by the function structure.
• Range: The subset of the co-domain that the function actually maps the domain to.

question_text: What does it mean when we say that an element a is related to b under a relation R? Provide a concise definition.
correct_answer: It means that the ordered pair (a, b) is an element of the relation R, i.e., (a, b) ∈ R.
explanation: In the language of relations, if a is related to b under R, we mean that the pair (a, b) satisfies the condition defined by R. No further conditions (like uniqueness) are assumed unless R is a function.

question_text: Explain how the concept of a relation in mathematics is inspired by the general English meaning of 'relation'.
correct_answer: In everyday English, a relation between objects means there exists a recognizable connection or link between them. In mathematics, a relation abstracts this idea by considering any association (subset) between elements of two sets, regardless of whether the connection is meaningful or defined by a particular rule.
explanation: The concept borrows the intuitive notion of 'relatedness' from English, where two items are connected by some property (like family ties or similarity), and extends it to any subset of the Cartesian product of two sets. It moves from the specific to the general by not insisting on any particular nature of the connection.

question_text: Prove that if a function f is invertible, then it must be one-to-one.
correct_answer: Proof: Assume f: A → B is invertible. This means there exists a function g: B → A such that g(f(a)) = a for all a in A and f(g(b)) = b for all b in B. Suppose, for contradiction, that f is not one-to-one. Then there exist distinct a1, a2 in A such that f(a1) = f(a2). Now applying g to both sides, we have g(f(a1)) = g(f(a2)) which implies a1 = a2, a contradiction. Therefore, f must be one-to-one.
explanation:
Step 1: Begin by assuming f is invertible, so an inverse function g exists.
Step 2: A function f is invertible only if g(f(a)) = a for each a in A. 
Step 3: Assume f is not one-to-one, implying there is a1 ≠ a2 with f(a1) = f(a2).
Step 4: Apply g to both sides to obtain a contradiction: g(f(a1)) = a1 and g(f(a2)) = a2, leading to a1 = a2.
Step 5: Since this contradicts a1 ≠ a2, f must be one-to-one.

question_text: Discuss the composition of functions and prove that the composition of two one-to-one functions is also one-to-one.
correct_answer: Proof: Let f: A → B and g: B → C be two one-to-one functions. Consider the composition h = g ∘ f: A → C, defined by h(a) = g(f(a)). Assume h(a1) = h(a2) for some a1, a2 in A. Then g(f(a1)) = g(f(a2)). Since g is one-to-one, it follows that f(a1) = f(a2). Then, by the one-to-one property of f, we deduce that a1 = a2. Hence, h is one-to-one.
explanation:
Step 1: Define the composition h = g ∘ f and assume h(a1) = h(a2).
Step 2: Write this as g(f(a1)) = g(f(a2)).
Step 3: Since g is one-to-one, we have f(a1) = f(a2).
Step 4: Using the one-to-one nature of f, conclude that a1 = a2.
Step 5: Therefore, the composition h is one-to-one.

question_text: In a school, Class XII has 30 students and Class XI has 25 students. What is the maximum possible number of ordered pairs in any relation from the set of Class XII students (A) to the set of Class XI students (B)?
explanation: The maximum number of ordered pairs in any relation from A to B is equal to the size of the Cartesian product A×B. Given |A| = 30 and |B| = 25, the total number is 30 × 25 = 750.

question_text: Given a function f: ℝ → ℝ defined by f(x) = 2x + 3, find the inverse function f⁻¹(x).
explanation: To find the inverse function, set y = f(x) = 2x + 3. Then swap x and y to get x = 2y + 3. Solving for y gives: 2y = x - 3, so y = (x - 3)/2. Therefore, f⁻¹(x) = (x - 3)/2.

question_text: Let f: ℝ → ℝ be defined by f(x) = 3x - 4. Compute the composition (f ∘ f)(x) and simplify the result.
explanation: First, compute f(f(x)). Given f(x) = 3x - 4, substitute into itself: f(f(x)) = f(3x - 4) = 3(3x - 4) - 4 = 9x - 12 - 4 = 9x - 16.

question_text: Which of the following best describes an empty relation on a set A?
options: A relation R with no ordered pairs, i.e. R = ∅
A relation R that relates every element of A with itself only
A relation R that relates each element of A with every element of A
A relation R that is symmetric but not reflexive
correct_answer: A relation R with no ordered pairs, i.e. R = ∅
explanation: By definition, an empty relation on a set A is one that does not contain any ordered pairs, meaning R = ∅, and hence no element of A is related to any element of A.

question_text: In a boys' school, consider the relation R defined by: 'a is the sister of b'. Which of the following is true about R?
options: R is a universal relation
R is an equivalence relation
R is an empty relation
R is reflexive
correct_answer: R is an empty relation
explanation: Since the school is exclusively for boys, no student can be a sister to any other student. Therefore, the relation R is empty (R = ∅).

question_text: Which of the following properties is NOT required for a relation to be an equivalence relation?
options: Reflexivity
Symmetry
Transitivity
Antisymmetry
correct_answer: Antisymmetry
explanation: An equivalence relation must be reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. Antisymmetry is not a requirement for equivalence relations; it is a property associated with order relations.

question_text: Consider the relation R on the set A = {1, 2, 3, 4} defined by R = {(a, b) : b = a + 1}. Which of the following is true about R?
options: R is symmetric and transitive
R is only reflexive
R is neither symmetric nor transitive
R is an equivalence relation
correct_answer: R is neither symmetric nor transitive
explanation: In R, for example, (1,2) ∈ R but (2,1) ∉ R, so it is not symmetric. Also, (1,2) and (2,3) are in R, but (1,3) ∉ R, so it is not transitive. Moreover, it is not reflexive because (a, a) ∉ R.

question_text: Define an empty relation in your own words.
correct_answer: An empty relation on a set A is a relation that contains no ordered pairs from A × A; that is, no element of A is related to any element of A.
explanation: This definition follows directly from the textbook explanation: if a relation R has no elements, R = ∅, then it is called an empty relation because there is no pair (a, b) ∈ R.

question_text: Explain what is meant by a universal relation and give an example.
correct_answer: A universal relation in a set A is one in which every element of A is related to every other element of A, i.e., R = A × A. An example is the relation on any set where the condition is always true, such as R = {(a, b) ∈ A × A: |a - b| ≥ 0}.
explanation: Since the condition |a - b| ≥ 0 holds for all a, b ∈ A, every pair is included, making the relation universal.

question_text: List and briefly define the three key properties that a relation must satisfy to be an equivalence relation.
correct_answer:
The three key properties are:
1. Reflexivity: Every element is related to itself, i.e., for all a ∈ A, (a, a) ∈ R.
2. Symmetry: If an element a is related to b, then b is related to a, i.e., if (a, b) ∈ R then (b, a) ∈ R.
3. Transitivity: If an element a is related to b and b is related to c, then a is related to c, i.e., if (a, b) ∈ R and (b, c) ∈ R then (a, c) ∈ R.
explanation: These properties together ensure that the relation partitions the set into disjoint equivalence classes where elements in the same class are equivalent by the relation.

question_text: Describe an example of a relation that is symmetric but not transitive, and explain why it fails to be transitive.
correct_answer: An example is the relation R on the set of lines in a plane defined by: L₁ R L₂ if L₁ is perpendicular to L₂. This relation is symmetric because if L₁ is perpendicular to L₂, then L₂ is perpendicular to L₁. However, it is not transitive because if L₁ is perpendicular to L₂ and L₂ is perpendicular to L₃, then L₁ is parallel to L₃ and not perpendicular in general.
explanation: For transitivity to hold, if L₁ ⟂ L₂ and L₂ ⟂ L₃, then we should have L₁ ⟂ L₃, but parallel lines are not perpendicular. Thus, transitivity fails.

question_text: Prove that the relation R defined on ℤ by a R b if and only if 2 divides (a - b) is an equivalence relation.
correct_answer:
Proof:
1. Reflexivity: For any integer a, a - a = 0, and 2 divides 0. Hence, (a, a) ∈ R.
2. Symmetry: If 2 divides (a - b), then (a - b) is even, so (b - a) is also even. Thus, 2 divides (b - a) and (b, a) ∈ R.
3. Transitivity: If 2 divides (a - b) and 2 divides (b - c), then (a - b) + (b - c) = a - c is even. Therefore, 2 divides (a - c), which implies (a, c) ∈ R.
Thus, R is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive, making it an equivalence relation.
explanation: The proof checks each required property for an equivalence relation. Reflexivity is shown by noting 0 is even; symmetry follows from the property of even numbers; transitivity is established by summing two even numbers, yielding an even number.

question_text: Prove that the relation R on the set L of all lines in a plane defined as L₁ R L₂ if L₁ is perpendicular to L₂ is symmetric but not reflexive or transitive.
correct_answer:
Proof:
1. Symmetry: Assume L₁ is perpendicular to L₂. By definition of perpendicularity, L₂ is also perpendicular to L₁, so (L₂, L₁) ∈ R.
2. Not Reflexive: For any line L, it is not possible for L to be perpendicular to itself, so (L, L) ∉ R.
3. Not Transitive: Consider three lines L₁, L₂, and L₃ such that L₁ ⟂ L₂ and L₂ ⟂ L₃. In Euclidean geometry, if two lines are each perpendicular to a third line, they are parallel but not necessarily perpendicular to each other. Therefore, (L₁, L₃) ∉ R.
Thus, R is symmetric but fails reflexivity and transitivity.
explanation: The proof involves direct application of definitions. The symmetric property follows immediately from the definition of perpendicularity. Reflexivity fails because a line cannot be perpendicular to itself, and transitivity fails as parallel lines result in the breakdown of the perpendicular relation.

question_text: Given the relation R on ℤ by a R b if 2 divides (a - b), list the equivalence classes of ℤ under R and explain your answer.
correct_answer: The equivalence classes are [0] = {…, -4, -2, 0, 2, 4, …} (all even integers) and [1] = {…, -3, -1, 1, 3, …} (all odd integers).
explanation: Since two integers have the same parity if their difference is even, all even numbers belong to one equivalence class and all odd numbers belong to the other. For any integer a, if a is even then a ~ 0, and if a is odd then a ~ 1.

question_text: Consider the set A = {1, 2, 3}. The relation R is defined on A as R = {(1,1), (2,2), (3,3), (1,2), (2,3)}. Determine whether R is reflexive, symmetric, and transitive, providing reasons for your answer.
correct_answer: R is reflexive because all elements relate to themselves. R is not symmetric because (1,2) ∈ R but (2,1) ∉ R. R is not transitive because (1,2) ∈ R and (2,3) ∈ R, yet (1,3) ∉ R.
explanation: Reflexivity is checked by ensuring (a,a) exists for all a in A. Symmetry is violated when an ordered pair does not appear in its reverse, as shown by (1,2) vs. (2,1). Transitivity fails because the chain 1 → 2 and 2 → 3 does not close to 1 → 3.

question_text: For the relation R on ℤ defined by a R b if and only if 3 divides (a - b), determine the equivalence classes for the integers from -4 to 4.
correct_answer:
The equivalence classes are as follows:
• [0] = {..., -6, -3, 0, 3, 6, ...} contains -3, 0, 3.
• [1] = {..., -5, -2, 1, 4, 7, ...} contains -2, 1, 4.
• [2] = {..., -4, -1, 2, 5, 8, ...} contains -4, -1, 2.
Thus, from -4 to 4, the members are grouped into these three classes.

question_text: For the set A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7}, consider the relation R defined by: two numbers are related if both are odd or both are even. Identify the equivalence classes and justify your answer.
correct_answer: The equivalence classes are {1, 3, 5, 7} (all odd numbers) and {2, 4, 6} (all even numbers).
explanation: Since the relation groups numbers based on parity, all odd numbers are related to one another and all even numbers are related to one another. There is no relation between an odd and an even number. This partitions the set A into the two classes as given.
